speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: If you live in a city, you’re probably familiar with this very modern sight: a man walking his dog drops a little black plastic bag into a rubbish bin. Inside the bag is dog poo.

speaker: Sam
text: It might make it seem that humans are hygienic creatures - certainly cleaner than dogs, who go to the toilet wherever they want. But is this the whole story?

speaker: Neil
text: How do us humans compare with other animals when it comes to keeping ourselves and our environment clean? In this programme, we’ll be asking whether humans as a species are naturally clean and tidy.

speaker: Sam
text: In fact, from dumping raw sewage into rivers to littering the streets with trash, humans aren’t always good at dealing with waste.

speaker: Neil
text: While some animals, on the other hand, are instinctively clean.

speaker: Sam
text: Right - cats for example dig a hole to bury their poo.

speaker: Neil
text: In the past, humans got rid of their waste by throwing it into the street or into streams and rivers, hoping the water would wash it away.

speaker: Out of sight out of mind
text: Out of sight out of mind! That’s a phrase used to say that it’s easier to forget something when you can’t see it.

speaker: Neil
text: But this doesn’t always work, as we’ll discover from my quiz question, Sam. In Victorian times, the population of London boomed and so did all the pee and poo being thrown into the River Thames. It got so bad that by the 1850s the awful smell had its own name – but what? Was it:

speaker: Neil
text: A) The Great Stench?,

speaker: Neil
text: B) The Great Stink?,  or

speaker: Neil
text: C) The Great Smell?

speaker: Sam
text: Ugh! All sounds pretty disgusting, Neil, but I’ll go for A) The Great Stench.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out if that’s right later. Earlier you mentioned cats as examples of animals who hide their waste, but leaf-cutter ants go even further: they kill any dirty ants trying to re-enter the group!

speaker: Sam
text: Zoologist, Professor Adam Hart, has spent years studying ants and other clean creatures. Here he is speaking with BBC World Service programme, The Conversation:

speaker: go to quite great lengthsterritorial markers
text: Some animals, you’ll be watching, and it is just pouring out of the back end and they don’t seem to care. Other animals will go to quite great lengths to go to a specific area. Some antelope for example will go to a sort of latrine area. It’s really linked to their ecology so quite often animals are using dung and also urine as marking posts and territorial markers to say to other groups of animals and other individuals that, well, this is my territory not yours.

speaker: go to great lengths,
text: Like cats and ants, antelopes go to great lengths, meaning they try very hard to do something, in this case to leave their poo - or dung - in a specific area, away from their home.

speaker: territorial markers
text: Antelopes leave smells, called territorial markers, secreted in urine, or pee, to tell other animals that an area of land is already occupied.

speaker: Neil
text: OK Sam, but just because most of us don’t pee at the bottom of the garden, does that necessarily mean humans are dirtier?

speaker: Sam
text: Well, no, not according to psychologist, Dr Michael De Barra. He thinks that human attitudes to cleanliness are related to the problem of infectious diseases, something we’ve all experienced during the Covid pandemic.

speaker: Neil
text: Here is Dr De Barra, explaining more to BBC World Service’s, The Conversation:

speaker: disgust nausea
text: So, in humans it seems like the emotion disgust is a big part of how we deal with infectious diseases problems. It’s characterised by avoidance, by sometimes feelings of nausea and what’s interesting about it is that it is elicited by many of the things that are infectious disease threats in our environment… so that might be particular smells, or particular substances, body wastes, physical signs of infectious disease – coughs, sneezes.

speaker: disgust
text: Our natural reaction to something which is dirty, and which therefore may be diseased and harmful to us, is disgust – a strong feeling of dislike or repulsion.

speaker: nausea
text: We might feel so disgusted at the sight or smell of human waste that we actually want to vomit – a feeling known as nausea.

speaker: Sam
text: These bodily reactions are the immune system’s way of saying: keep away! – this will make you sick!

speaker: Neil
text: So, although getting a bit dirty won’t kill you (unless you’re a leaf-cutter ant), human evolution has developed a psychological way of keeping us clean. What’s the matter, Sam? You look a little green!

speaker: Sam
text: I am, Neil! All this talk of pee and poo is disgusting! And just image how bad it must’ve been in the old days.

speaker: Neil
text: Like in Victorian times before the invention of modern sewers and sanitation. In my quiz question I asked you what people called the awful smell in London in the 1850s.

speaker: Sam
text: And I said it was A) The Great Stench. Was I right?

speaker: Neil
text: You were… wrong! In fact, the answer was B) The Great Stink, which stunk up the River Thames all the way to Westminster. It was only when the smell reached the noses of politicians in Parliament that something was done about it…

speaker: to raise a stink about something
text: …so starting another useful phrase – to raise a stink about something, meaning to make a strong public complaint.

speaker: out of sight, out of mind,
text: OK, let’s recap the other vocabulary, starting with out of sight, out of mind, a phrase meaning that it’s easier to forget something when you can’t see it.

speaker: go to great lengths
text: To go to great lengths means to try very hard to achieve something.

speaker: Territorial markers
text: Territorial markers are smells in animals’ dung or urine marking their territory.

speaker: disgust nausea -
text: These may fill you with disgust – a feeling of strong dislike or repulsion. Or even give you nausea - the feeling that you are going to vomit.

speaker: Neil
text: And that’s all for this stinky edition of 6 Minute English. Join us again soon for more topical chat and useful vocabulary. Bye for now!

speaker: Sam
text: Bye!
